name: Drawing and interpreting histograms (equal class width)

explanations.A: It looks like you have noted the frequency of the histogram. We need to find a data set that could be represented by the histogram. Which data set has 4 data points greater than or equal to 0, but less than 10?
explanations.B: It seems you just gave the end points on the time axis. We need to find a data set that could be represented by the histogram. Which data set has 4 data points between 0 and 10?
explanations.C: Remember, the endpoints are located in bin to the right.
explanations.D: The first bin has a frequency of 4 and bin values 0 ≤ x < 10, so 1, 5, 8, 9 meet this criteria. The second bin has a frequency of 7 and bin values of 10 ≤ x < 20, so 11, 13, 13, 15, 16, 18, 19 meet this criteria. The third bin has a frequency of 3 and bin values of 20 ≤ x < 30, so 21, 25, 28 meet this criteria. This data set matches the histogram.

explanations.A: Remember, the endpoints are located in bin to the right.
explanations.B: The first bin has a frequency of 2 and bin values 0 ≤ x < 10, so 4, 7 meet this criteria. The second bin has a frequency of 6 and bin values of 10 ≤ x < 20, so 12, 14, 15, 16, 17, 19 meet this criteria. The third bin has a frequency of 5 and bin values of 20 ≤ x < 30, so 22, 24, 25, 27, 27 meet this criteria. This data set matches the histogram.
explanations.C: It seems you just gave the end points on the time axis. We need to find a data set that could be represented by the histogram. Which data set has 2 data points greater than or equal to 0, but less than 10?
explanations.D: It looks like you have noted the frequency of the histogram. We need to find a data set that could be represented by the histogram. Which data set has 2 data points greater than or equal to 0, but less than 10?

explanations.A: While 0 is the lower boundary, we can't know how many, if any of the data values are 0 seconds. What range would the quickest time be in?
explanations.B: While 10 is the upper boundary, we can't know how many, if any of the data values are 10 seconds. What range would the quickest time be in?
explanations.C: It seems you have confused the quickest time with the range of longest times. Which range is the shortest times?
explanations.D: We don't know the exact value but we know the quickest time is located between 0 and 10 seconds.

explanations.A: We don't know the exact value but the slowest time is located between 20 and 30 seconds.
explanations.B: While 20 is the lower boundary, we can't know how many, if any of the data values are 20 seconds. What range would the slowest time be in?
explanations.C: It seems you have confused the slowest time with the range of shortest times. Which range is the slowest times?
explanations.D: While 30 is the upper boundary, we can't know how many, if any of the data values are 30 seconds. What range would the slowest time be in?

explanations.A: It looks like you have noted the frequency of the histogram. We need to find a data set that could be represented by the histogram. Which data set has 2 data points greater than or equal to 0, but less than 10?
explanations.B: The first bin has a frequency of 2 and bin values 0 ≤ x < 10, so 1, 5 meet this criteria. The second bin has a frequency of 5 and bin values of 10 ≤ x < 20, so 11, 13, 15, 18, 19 meet this criteria. The third bin has a frequency of 4 and bin values of 20 ≤ x < 30, so 22, 25, 28, 29 meet this criteria. The fourth bin has a frequency of 1 and bin values 30 ≤ x < 40, so 35 meets this criteria. This data set matches the histogram.
explanations.C: It seems you just gave the end points on the time axis. We need to find a data set that could be represented by the histogram. Which data set has 2 data points between 0 and 10?
explanations.D: Remember, the endpoints are located in bin to the right.

explanations.A: It seems you just gave the end points on the time axis. We need to find a data set that could be represented by the histogram. Which data set has 4 data points between 10 and 20?
explanations.B: It looks like you have noted the frequency of the histogram. We need to find a data set that could be represented by the histogram. Which data set has 4 data points greater than or equal to 10, but less than 20?
explanations.C: 23, 24, 27, 29 would all go in the 20 ≤ x < 30 bin but looking at the histogram we need 3 data points in this bin
explanations.D: The first bin has a frequency of 4 and bin values 10 ≤ x < 20, so 12, 15, 17, 19 meet this criteria. The second bin has a frequency of 3 and bin values of 20 ≤ x < 30, so 24, 25, 28 meet this criteria. The third bin has a frequency of 5 and bin values of 30 ≤ x < 40, so 31, 32, 35, 36, 37 meet this criteria. The fourth bin has a frequency of 2 and bin values 40 ≤ x < 50, so 43, 46 meet this criteria. This data set matches the histogram.

explanations.A: While we can tell 10cm is in the bin with the highest frequency, can we tell how many, if any values in that bin have a height of 10cm?
explanations.B: 20cm is an endpoint and would be located in the bin to the right. Can we tell by looking at a histogram how many specific heights are located in a bin?
explanations.C: I think you found the midpoint of the tallest bar in your histogram. While that is a good estimate, can we be sure how many, if any values in that bin have a height of 15cm?
explanations.D: We can tell from the frequency which bin has the most data values, but we cannot tell what the most common height is because we can't see specific data values in a histogram.

explanations.A: We can tell from the frequency which bin has the most data values, but we cannot tell what the most common height is because we can't see specific data values in a histogram.
explanations.B: I think you found the midpoint of the tallest bar in your histogram. While that is a good estimate, can we be sure how many, if any values in that bin have a height of 45cm?
explanations.C: While we can tell 30cm is in the bin with the highest frequency, can we tell how many, if any values in that bin have a height of 30cm?
explanations.D: 50cm is an endpoint and would be located in the bin to the right. Can we tell by looking at a histogram how many specific heights are located in a bin?

explanations.A: The existing value in the bin is greater than or equal to 30, but less than 40. Is 40 greater than that range?
explanations.B: I think you believe the value has to be within the range of the largest bin, but the height axis could be extended.
explanations.C: There is already 1 value in this bin, and that value is at least 30, so another value of 30 cannot be the tallest, but would be, at best, equal in height.
explanations.D: If the existing value in the bin is 30cm, then is 31 greater than 30?

explanations.A: The existing values in the bin are greater than or equal to 40, but less than 50. Is 50 greater than that range?
explanations.B: I think you believe the value has to be within the range of the largest bin, but the height axis could be extended.
explanations.C: If the existing values in the bin are all 40cm, then is 41 greater than 40?
explanations.D: There are already 2 values in this bin, and those values are at least 40, so another value of 40 cannot be the tallest, but would be, at best, equal in height.
